title: Is a person eligible to file for Chapter 7 Bankruptcy if they haven't filed a tax return in several years?
question: For Chapter 7 bankruptcy, do you have to be current on your income tax returns? For example, if I haven't filed my taxes since 2003, would I need to file them before I file for a Chapter 7 bankruptcy?
answers:
Eligibility to file Chapter 7 has nothing to do with your tax returns. Eligibility to file is based on an average of what you have earned during the past 6 months & whether you have any amount of money left over to pay your debts.

So why is everyone talking about your tax returns? Because in order to complete your Chapter 7 case, the Trustee will require you to produce your tax returns so that s/he can evaluate your financial circumstances. Unless you can document that you have no legal obligation to file taxes (and don't come in with some bogus argument about being a tax protestor or being a church), no tax returns means that the trustee will ultimately ask that your Chapter 7 be dismissed for your failure to cooperate.

What I am saying is that there is a difference between being eligible and being able to fulfill the requirements of a Chapter 7. Even if you haven't filed returns for many years, you can file & have the returns prepared later. Just don't keep putting it off or you will hang yourself.

Hope this perspective helps!

I agree with my colleague. However, the implication in your question is that you are required to file taxes but have not done so. The answer is still yes. You are eligible to file, however, you may not receive a discharge. With the changes to the bankruptcy code in 2005 came a new requirement which is codified. That requirement is to provide recent tax returns to the Trustee. Without providing those returns the trustee can request your case be dismissed for a number a reasons including non-compliance with this rule.

If you were required under the IRS Code to file a return then you need to comply with the law. While filing back tax returns can seem daunting it can be simplified. Go to the local IRS office and request transcripts for the years in question. The information you are looking for is what income was reported for the years in question. That is the starting point.

You should be aware that you can not discharge back taxes owed from years when you did not file the returns. Get a CPA and a bankruptcy attorney. This can be accomplished.

There is no requirement that you must be current on your income tax returns for filing a Chapter 7 bankruptcy. That requirement arises in Chapter 13; a Chapter 13 Plan cannot be confirmed if tax returns for the preceding four tax years have not been filed, and the returns must be filed no later than the day before the 341 hearing (this deadline can be extended by the Trustee). In both a Chapter 7 and Chapter 13 bankruptcy cases, the filer must provide the Bankruptcy Trustee with a copy of the most recently filed tax return or tax transcript at least 7 days prior to the 341 hearing, as well as any creditor who requests a copy. This can be difficult if it has been many years since a return has been filed as, if many years have passed, no return or transcript may be available. In such a case, the bankruptcy filer can submit a sworn declaration to the trustee stating that they have not filed tax returns in X number of years and that copies of prior filings are unavailable, which will normally satisfy this requirement.

You can file the bankruptcy but the IRS is likely to object to the discharge and the case could be dismissed without a discharge if the IRS objects. You should file all taxes before the bankruptcy. The taxes you owe are not dischargeable because you did not file in time.

Income Taxes are (possibly) dischargeable in bankruptcy if they are for taxes that became due for tax years greater than three (3) years ago; the tax return was filed at least two (20 years ago; the taxes were “assessed at least 240 days ago, and there was no indication that there was fraud or evasion of taxes.

Having stated the broad general rules, let me note that there are many, many, many ways that taxes can become non-dischargeable in the event certain things happened or did not happen since the tax liability was assessed.

This is not something to attempt on your own, nor should an inexperienced Bankruptcy attorney rely on this broad outline. See a Bankruptcy attorney with sufficient experience to determine if any of the tax liability is dischargeable.

Good Luck!

In a word, yes, but you need to have a valid reason for not filing. For example, some people are on a very low fixed income such as Social Security and have no other income sources which the IRS will often accept as a valid reason to not follow. You will have to show to the Trustee at your 341 meeting that you are not required to file taxes. If you do not have a valid excuse the Trustee can insist that you file taxes prior to recommending a Chapter 7 discharge so be forewarned.
